pareto_frontier.name: Genesis
pareto_frontier.prompt_text: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

all_prompts.name: Genesis
all_prompts.prompt_text: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

reflection_insights: The mentor excelled at validating feelings and providing specific, low-stakes scripts, which built trust. However, the advice remained cognitive and didn't address the student's acute physical anxiety symptoms. For similar students, pair practical scripts with a simple physical grounding technique to help manage the anxiety in the moment.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hi, thanks for meeting with me. I've been really struggling with the social aspects of college, especially the group projects in my computer science courses.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 2/10 (Introverted)
- Agreeableness: 9/10 (Very cooperative)
- Conscientiousness: 8/10 (Very organized)
- Neuroticism: 4/10 (Moderately sensitive)
- Openness: 1/10 (More traditional)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 9/10 (Severe)
- Communication style: Direct
- Triggers: Office hours, Group projects, Job interviews, Presentations
- Social comfort: 2/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Finding a job after graduation, Living away from family for the first time, Time management with coursework
- Goals: Develop leadership skills, Build a strong professional network
- Challenges: Career exploration, Dealing with academic pressure, Navigating campus politics, Building time management
- Behaviors: Joins student clubs and organizations, Procrastinates on assignments, Calls family frequently, Studies in the library regularly, Stays up late studying

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey! I totally get it—group projects can be tough, especially when you're feeling anxious. Start small: maybe suggest a virtual coffee chat with one group member first to break the ice. Use tools like shared docs or Trello to stay organized and reduce pressure. Remember, everyone’s a bit nervous, and your tech skills are valuable! You’ve got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Honestly, just thinking about reaching out to a group member makes my chest feel tight. I always worry I'll say something awkward or bother them.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That’s completely understandable—I’ve felt that way too. Try sending a low-pressure message first, like: “Hey, I was reviewing the project and had a couple ideas. Mind if I share them here?” It gives you time to think and keeps things focused. You’re not bothering them; you’re contributing! Small steps build confidence.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I can try sending a message like that, but I'll probably rewrite it ten times first. What if they think my ideas are stupid?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That’s a normal worry—I rewrite messages all the time too! Remember, your ideas are valuable, and group projects are about collaboration, not perfection. Everyone brings something unique. Start with just one message and hit send before you overthink. You’re capable and your input matters!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but my hands still get shaky just thinking about hitting send. What if they don't respond at all?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That’s okay—shaking hands and all. If they don’t reply right away, it’s likely about their own schedule, not you. Give it a day, then a gentle follow-up is totally normal. Every message you send is practice, and you're building courage with each one. I believe in you!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I'll try the gentle follow-up if needed, but the silence after sending a message always makes me feel like I've done something wrong.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That feeling of silence is so real—I get it too. Remind yourself: no response usually means they’re busy, not upset. You’re doing the right thing by communicating. Each time you reach out, you’re strengthening your teamwork skills, and that’s exactly what employers value. Keep going—you’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, I'll try to remember that. It's just hard not to take it personally when the chat goes quiet after I speak up.

responses.question: I initiate conversations with new people.
I maintain eye contact during conversations.
I express my opinions clearly in group settings.
I listen actively when others are speaking.
I ask for help when I need it.
I handle criticism constructively.
I collaborate effectively in team projects.
I adapt my communication style to different situations.
I manage conflicts calmly and respectfully.
I show appreciation and give compliments to others.
I read social cues and body language accurately.
I share personal experiences to connect with others.
I participate actively in class discussions.
I build rapport with classmates and colleagues.
I negotiate compromises when disagreements arise.
I speak confidently in professional settings.
I network effectively at events and gatherings.
I provide constructive feedback to peers.
I maintain relationships over time.
I adapt to different social and cultural contexts.

improvement_areas: I initiate conversations with new people.
I maintain eye contact during conversations.
I express my opinions clearly in group settings.

responses.question: I ask for help when I need it.
I stay calm when dealing with problems.
I help my friends when they are having a problem.
I work well with my classmates.
I do the right thing without being told.
I do my part in a group.
I stay calm when I disagree with others.
I stand up for others when they are not treated well.
I look at people when I talk to them.
I am careful when I use things that aren't mine.
I let people know when there's a problem.
I pay attention when the teacher talks to the class.
I try to make others feel better.
I say "thank you" when someone helps me.
I keep my promises.
I pay attention when others present their ideas.
I try to find a good way to end a disagreement.
I try to think about how others feel.
I try to forgive others when they say "sorry."
I follow school rules.

improvement_areas: I ask for help when I need it.
I stay calm when dealing with problems.
I work well with my classmates.

reflection_insights:
**What worked:** Leveraging Gregory's high extraversion by suggesting direct outreach (e.g., emailing Professor Chen) was effective, as it played to his strengths and produced immediate action.

**What didn't:** The advice on finances remained too general; a more specific, immediate step (e.g., "Find the financial aid website right now") would have better addressed his acute anxiety.

**Key insight:** For highly extroverted students, channel their social energy into concrete, "do-this-now" tasks to break the cycle of overthinking and build momentum.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hey, thanks for meeting with me. Honestly, I’m just feeling a bit overwhelmed with everything and I’m not even sure where to start.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 10/10 (Very outgoing)
- Agreeableness: 1/10 (More competitive)
- Conscientiousness: 6/10 (Moderately organized)
- Neuroticism: 8/10 (Very sensitive to stress)
- Openness: 7/10 (Very creative and curious)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 3/10 (Low)
- Communication style: Passive
- Triggers: Networking events, Presentations, Campus social events
- Social comfort: 4/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Choosing the right career path, Social anxiety in large lecture halls, Academic failure and poor grades, Dealing with roommate conflicts
- Goals: Improve public speaking, Get accepted to graduate school, Publish a paper, Learn a new language
- Challenges: Financial planning, Finding a mentor, Managing student loans
- Behaviors: Eats at the dining hall, Participates in study groups, Volunteers for campus events

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Gregory, totally get that overwhelmed feeling—it hits most of us! Since you’re outgoing and open, start by using those strengths: reach out to a professor or upperclassman in CS for mentorship. They can help with grad school advice and even public speaking practice. For finances, check if your university offers free financial counseling—many do! Tackle one thing at a time; you’ve got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I've been meaning to ask Professor Chen about research opportunities, but I keep putting it off because I'm worried about sounding clueless. And honestly, the thought of managing these student loans after graduation is already keeping me up at night.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Professor Chen expects students to ask questions—it shows initiative! Just be honest: "I'm interested in research but new to this process. Could we discuss potential opportunities?" For loans, schedule one session with financial aid to create a repayment plan. Breaking big worries into small actions helps. You're capable of handling both!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but my brain just spirals thinking about how every decision feels so permanent right now. Maybe I'll email Professor Chen after our session though.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That’s a great first step—emailing Professor Chen is a win! Remember, most decisions aren’t permanent, and it’s okay to adjust as you go. You’re proactive and curious—use that to explore options without pressure. You’ve got the drive to figure things out step by step.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I'll draft that email right now before I lose my nerve. It's just... sometimes I wish someone would just tell me exactly what path to take instead of having to figure it all out myself.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: I hear you—that uncertainty is tough. But your willingness to draft that email shows real courage. No one has it all figured out, and your path will unfold as you take these small, brave steps. Trust your curiosity and strengths. You're doing better than you think!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Honestly, I wish I had your confidence—sometimes I feel like I'm just pretending to know what I'm doing. But you're right, sending that email is better than staying stuck in my own head.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That "pretending" feeling is so common—it's called imposter syndrome, and even the most successful people experience it. The key isn't having all the answers; it's taking action despite the doubt, just like you are by sending that email. Every step forward builds real confidence. You're not pretending—you're *progressing*. Keep going!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, I really needed to hear that today. It's just hard when everyone around me seems so certain about their futures while I'm still figuring out basic things like how to afford next semester's textbooks.

responses.question: I ask for help when I need it.
I stay calm when dealing with problems.
I listen carefully to what others are saying.
I express my feelings clearly.
I work well in groups.
I handle criticism well.
I start conversations easily.
I respect other people's opinions.
I manage my time effectively.
I adapt well to new situations.
I resolve conflicts peacefully.
I show appreciation for others.
I maintain eye contact during conversations.
I accept responsibility for my mistakes.
I consider others' feelings before acting.
I speak clearly and confidently.
I follow through on commitments.
I handle stressful situations well.
I make others feel comfortable.
I balance speaking and listening in conversations.

improvement_areas: I ask for help when I need it.
I stay calm when dealing with problems.
I listen carefully to what others are saying.
